tit.e: Metsuke (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu)
Metsuke (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu)
Metsuke (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu)

sen.e: What is Metsuke?
Metsuke is
sen.cmt: フォーマルでないため変更しました。
sen.e: Metsuke is

sen.j: 江戸幕府における職名の一つ。
sen.e: It was a governmental post of the Edo bakufu.
A governmental post of the Edo bakufu.
sen.cmt: 前の文とつながるように変更しました。It isを削除。
sen.e: A governmental post of the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: 戦国大名が合戦後に、論功行賞を行うため獲得した首を検分する役職として設けた職名の一つ。
sen.e: It was one of the posts that daimyo in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) established for making the human heads, brought by their subordinates after a battle, checked for granting appropriate rewards.

It was one of the posts that daimyo in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) established for checking the human heads, brought by their subordinates after a battle, for granting appropriate rewards.
sen.cmt: 文法的誤りのため変更しました。making the human heads, brought by their subordinates after a battle, checked →checking the human heads, brought by their subordinates after a battle,
sen.e: It was one of the posts that daimyo in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) established for checking the human heads, brought by their subordinates after a battle, for granting appropriate rewards.

sen.j: 武道などにおいて相対したときの相手に対する目の付けどころ。
sen.e: This term is also used for indicating, for example, in a martial art, the other one's body part where one of the two players facing each other pays special attention.
one's body part to which their opponent pays their special attention
sen.cmt: 不自然なため変更しました。the other one's body part where one of the two players facing each other pays special attention. → one's body part to which their opponent pays their special attention
sen.e: one's body part to which their opponent pays their special attention

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)、将士や敵の内情を監視して、主君に通報する者に由来するといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that this term was originated in the persons who, in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), watched the states of soldiers, their leaders and enemies, and reported them to their lords.

It is said that this term was originated in the persons who, in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), watched the states of soldiers, their leaders and enemies, and reported them to their lords.

It is said that this term was originated in the persons who, in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), watched the states of soldiers, their leaders and enemies, and reported them to their lords.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の若年寄の目耳になって旗本・御家人を監察した。
sen.e: In the Edo bakufu, the officers in this post watched for Wakatoshiyori (governmental officers in the bakufu) the states of Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu) and Gokenin (also direct retainers of the bakufu, but lower-ranked than Hatamoto).

In the Edo bakufu, the officers in this post watched for Wakatoshiyori (governmental officers in the bakufu) the states of Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu) and Gokenin (also direct retainers of the bakufu, but lower-ranked than Hatamoto).

In the Edo bakufu, the officers in this post watched for Wakatoshiyori (governmental officers in the bakufu) the states of Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu) and Gokenin (also direct retainers of the bakufu, but lower-ranked than Hatamoto).
This post was established in 1617, and the number of the officers was up to 10.
This post was established in 1617, and the number of the officers was up to 10.
This post was established in 1617, and the number of the officers was up to 10.

sen.j: 諸藩にも同様の制度があった。
sen.e: Posts similar to this were established in domains as well.
Posts similar to this were established in domains as well.
Posts similar to this were established in domains as well.

sen.j: また徒目付・歩行目付などと云われる役職もあったが、これらは、幕府御家人や、諸藩の足軽の戦果及び、勤務を監察した。
sen.e: A post called Kachi-metsuke or Hoko-metsuke was also placed to watch the fighting results and job statues of Gokenin and Ashigaru (common foot soldiers).
A post called Kachi-metsuke or Hoko-metsuke was also placed to watch the fighting results and job statues of Gokenin and Ashigaru (common foot soldiers).
A post called Kachi-metsuke or Hoko-metsuke was also placed to watch the fighting results and job statues of Gokenin and Ashigaru (common foot soldiers).
